title: Apteribis
text:
Apteribis is an <a href="extinction">extinct</a> <a href="genus">genus</a> of <a href="flightless%20bird">flightless bird</a>s in the <a href="ibis">ibis</a> subfamily that was <a href="endemism">endemic</a> to the <a href="Hawaiian%20Islands">Hawaiian Islands</a> in the <a href="Pacific%20Ocean">Pacific Ocean</a>.
Distribution.
The remains of the small ibises in the genus have only been found on the islands of <a href="Maui">Maui</a>, <a href="Lanai">Lanai</a>, and <a href="Molokai">Molokai</a>, which formed part of the prehistoric island of <a href="Maui%20Nui">Maui Nui</a> until about 200,000 years ago when <a href="sea%20level%20rise">rising sea levels</a> fragmented it. Olson and <a href="Helen%20Frances%20James">James</a> speculate that the genus was endemic to Maui Nui, that the ibises were birds of the <a href="forest%20floor">forest floor</a>, that because of their flightlessness they were susceptible to becoming trapped in <a href="lava%20tube">lava tube</a>s, and that they may have exerted heavy <a href="predation">predation</a> pressure on Maui Nui's <a href="land%20snail">land snail</a>s.
Taxonomy.
Analysis of the feathers from the Lanai specimen show an affinity to New World ibises of the genus "<a href="Eudocimus">Eudocimus</a>". The analyses also concluded that "Apteribis" may have had a brown-and-beige coloration similar to that of a juvenile "Eudocimus" ibis. This indicates that "Apteribis" may have evolved both their flightlessness and their coloration through a form of <a href="Neoteny">paedomorphosis</a>.
Species.
Two species have been described:
The <a href="holotype">holotype</a> of "A. glenos" is from the <a href="Mo%CA%BBomomi">Moʻomomi dunes</a>, and other specimens are from <a href="Ilio%20Point">Ilio Point</a> and <a href="Kalaupapa%2C%20Hawaii">Kalaupapa peninsula</a>.
Fossil material collected on Maui indicates that a third species apparently occurred there; it was generally larger in size and occurred at lower elevations than "A. brevis", and has been referred to as the “Maui lowland apteribis”. Another, extremely well-preserved specimen has also been recovered from Lanai, though it has not yet been described to the species level.
